TITLE: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin tests positive for COVID-19
SUMMARY: Austin, 68, tested positive on Sunday. He said that his symptoms are mild, and he was fully vaccinated and boosted in October. He plans to continue with key meetings virtually during quarantine.

TITLE: This photographer captured how activists helped migrants at the Poland-Belarus border
SUMMARY: Polish-based photographer Kasia Strek documented what it was like for migrants and people in Poland as the crisis evolved at the border in November.

TITLE: FDA authorizes a Pfizer booster shot for children ages 12 to 15
SUMMARY: The agency also shortened the time between the completion of primary vaccination of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine and a booster dose, down to five months from six.

TITLE: The last living parent of a child killed in the 1963 Birmingham church bombing dies
SUMMARY: Maxine McNair's 11-year-old daughter, Denise McNair, was the youngest of the four Black girls killed in the bombing of Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church in 1963. She died Sunday at 93.

TITLE: With COVID outbreaks, Broadway's understudies take center stage
SUMMARY: Breakthrough infections from the omicron variant have been spreading like wildfire among casts and crews, so understudies and swing performers have been helping keep shows afloat.

TITLE: 6 questions for politics in 2022
SUMMARY: From control of Congress and the strength of the Biden presidency to potential Jan. 6 committee revelations and the future of abortion rights, there's a lot at stake in 2022.

TITLE: 6 in 10 Americans say U.S. democracy is in crisis as 'The Big Lie' takes root
SUMMARY: A year after the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, a new NPR/Ipsos poll finds that Americans are pessimistic about the future of democracy, as false claims about the 2020 election persist.

TITLE: Why your local library might be hiring a social worker
SUMMARY: Libraries in some cities are investing in staff members who can help patrons with complex issues such as housing insecurity, finding mental health and more.

TITLE: A year after Capitol Police's darkest day, its chief says the force is making gains
SUMMARY: Capitol Police Chief Tom Manger has been on the job less than six months. He hopes to lead a new chapter at the embattled agency.

TITLE: Seoul: North Korea defector likely made rare border crossing back
SUMMARY: A person who crossed the border from South Korea into North Korea on New Year's Day was likely a defector who had made the trip in the other direction in late 2020, the military said Monday.

TITLE: Quebec begins retail store closures amid new COVID-19 wave
SUMMARY: Quebec proceeded with the first of three planned closures of non-essential retail stores Sunday as the government tries to curb a new wave of COVID-19 driven by the highly infectious Omicron variant.

TITLE: Another Hong Kong news site shuts as pro-Beijing lawmakers sworn in
SUMMARY: A Hong Kong online news site said Sunday that it will cease operations in light of deteriorating press freedoms, days after police raided a separate pro-democracy news outlet, arresting seven.

TITLE: 2 remain missing after the Colorado fire. Survivors are counting their blessings
SUMMARY: The missing persons toll has dropped after one person was found alive. Residents who escaped the flames that destroyed some 1,000 homes returned to sort through what was left.

TITLE: Weekend storms bring damage to parts of Southern U.S.
SUMMARY: Severe storms took out power and destroyed homes in Alabama, hours after heavy rain and tornadoes tore through Kentucky. Several Alabama counties are under a tornado watch through early Monday.

TITLE: Sudan's prime minister announces his resignation amid political deadlock
SUMMARY: Abdalla Hamdok said Sunday that he will step down amid widespread protests condemn a military coup that derailed Sudan's shift to democratic rule. Over 50 protesters have died since the October coup.

TITLE: A federal court just released the settlement deal between Epstein and Giuffre
SUMMARY: The settlement between Jeffrey Epstein and Virginia Giuffre, one of his accusers, is emerging less than a week after his longtime partner Ghislaine Maxwell was found guilty of sex trafficking a minor.

TITLE: Famed fossil hunter and conservationist Richard Leakey dies at 77
SUMMARY: Leakey made important contributions to our understanding of human origins through his fossil finds. He later gained fame for taking on poachers who threatened to wipe out Kenya's elephants and rhinos.

TITLE: The FDA authorizes a Pfizer booster shot for children ages 12 to 15
SUMMARY: The authorization comes in the midst of an explosion of COVID-19 cases nationwide driven by the omicron variant — a surge that has brought a spike in pediatric hospitalizations.

TITLE: 2022 will be a tense year for Facebook and social apps. Here are 4 reasons why
SUMMARY: Social media companies will feel pressure from Washington, European regulators and even their own users over kids' safety and privacy, competition and election-related misinformation.

TITLE: 700 sheep and goats were arranged in the shape of a needle to encourage vaccinations
SUMMARY: A shepherd in Germany arranged her animals into a 330-foot syringe to encourage people to get vaccinated.

TITLE: New York's attorney general has subpoenaed Ivanka Trump and Donald Trump Jr.
SUMMARY: The subpoenas stem from an ongoing civil investigation into the Trump family's business practices. The former president has also been subpoenaed, and is now suing the attorney general.

TITLE: Schumer tees up vote on rules change if voting rights legislation is blocked
SUMMARY: It's the latest push by Senate Democrats to make good on their promise to pass voting rights legislation.

TITLE: A hockey fan spotted a staffer's suspicious mole from the stands, saving his life
SUMMARY: Kraken fan and future medical student Nadia Popovici alerted Canucks staffer Brian Hamilton to a suspicious mole, which turned out to be cancerous. The teams surprised her with a $10,000 scholarship.

TITLE: Fire reignites at South Africa's Parliament in Cape Town
SUMMARY: The fire started on Sunday and had been contained, but flared up again on Monday after firefighters had been sent home. A man was arrested in connection with the fire.

TITLE: Elizabeth Holmes trial: Jury is deadlocked on 3 of 11 fraud charges
SUMMARY: After hearing about the impasse, the judge instructed the jury to keep deliberating. Jurors have been debating Holmes' fate for seven days after a trial that has stretched on for four months.

TITLE: New Hampshire's longtime guardian of its early presidential primary is stepping down
SUMMARY: Secretary of State William Gardner, who earned a national reputation as gatekeeper of New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation presidential primary, has held the office since 1976.

TITLE: If you're clinging to an old BlackBerry, it will officially stop working on Jan. 4
SUMMARY: The company behind the once ubiquitous phones has transitioned to a security software focus, and says that starting on Tuesday, its classic devices will no longer reliably function.

TITLE: 700 sheep and goats were arranged in the shape of a syringe to encourage vaccinations
SUMMARY: A shepherd in Germany arranged her animals into a 330-foot syringe to encourage people to get vaccinated.

TITLE: Officials are determined to keep schools open, despite omicron
SUMMARY: As coronavirus cases, and pediatric hospitalizations, surge in the U.S., the majority of U.S. schools are staying open for in-person learning.

TITLE: Texas officials put the final death toll from last year's winter storm at 246
SUMMARY: The Texas Department of State Health Services adjusted the number of people who died from last February's storm to 246 people — up from July's tally of 210.

TITLE: Former Theranos CEO Elizabeth Holmes is found guilty on 4 counts in her fraud trial
SUMMARY: Holmes, who was once seen as one of the most promising leaders in Silicon Valley, could spend up to 20 years in prison for lying to investors and patients of the blood-testing company.

TITLE: Congress' doctor urges lawmakers to work remotely and upgrade masks as omicron rages
SUMMARY: The move follows an unprecedented spike in positivity rates in the Capitol, and mirrors record-high infection rates throughout Washington D.C., driven by the highly contagious omicron variant.

TITLE: Elizabeth Holmes verdict: Former Theranos CEO is found guilty on 4 counts
SUMMARY: Holmes, who was once seen as one of the most promising leaders in Silicon Valley, could spend up to 20 years in prison for defrauding investors of the blood-testing company.

TITLE: First Cambodian American mayor in U.S. takes office
SUMMARY: Sokhary Chau said his mother managed to keep her seven children alive for four years, surviving Cambodia's civil war to deliver them safely to the U.S.

TITLE: Teachers are on the front lines in Jan. 6 culture war
SUMMARY: Teachers now are left to decide how — or whether — to instruct their students about the events that sit at the heart of the country's division.

TITLE: Thousands of airline passengers are stranded. Here's what to do if you're one them
SUMMARY: Thousands of flights have been cancelled, leaving travelers scrambling to figure out how book new seats and get reimbursements for added expenses.

TITLE: Western Wall prayer site's future is in doubt under Israel's fragile government
SUMMARY: Israel's refusal to recognize liberal Reform and Conservative streams of Judaism has long been a point of tension with American Jews.

TITLE: Activists urge Tesla to close its new Xinjiang showroom
SUMMARY: Tesla on Friday announced the opening of its showroom in Urumqi, the capital of Xinjiang, where officials are accused of abuses against mostly Muslim ethnic minorities.

TITLE: Rep. Jamie Raskin searches for answers in 'Unthinkable' journey of trauma and grief
SUMMARY: In a new memoir, the Democratic congressman recounts a year of loss and grief after the death of son Tommy — and a motivation to right the wrongs that occurred on Jan. 6.

TITLE: Thousands of airline passengers are stranded. Here's what to do if you're one of them
SUMMARY: Thousands of flights have been canceled, leaving travelers scrambling to figure out how to book new seats and get reimbursements for added expenses.

TITLE: These are the numbers health officials are watching at this point in the pandemic
SUMMARY: In the midst of record COVID case numbers in the U.S., biostatistician Natalie Dean walks us through how to assess the metrics.

TITLE: The Washington Football Team will have a new name next month
SUMMARY: Two fan favorites have been ruled out: Team president Jason Wright says that anything involving "Wolves" or "Red Wolves" isn't possible, because of trademark conflicts.

TITLE: Child care is getting more support from some private companies
SUMMARY: Some corporations are trying harder to help provide child care for families.

TITLE: The CDC now recommends Pfizer boosters after 5 months, not 6
SUMMARY: The move to shorten the Pfizer booster interval comes as the U.S. shatters daily case records. The recommended interval for those who received Moderna or Johnson & Johnson vaccines has not changed.

TITLE: Novak Djokovic gets a vaccination exemption to play in the Australian Open
SUMMARY: The tournament's defending champion posted a photo of himself smiling at an airport. But in Australia, some of the responses to his Twitter post were not happy ones.

TITLE: Drivers have been stuck for hours in freezing temperatures after crashes block I-95
SUMMARY: Jackknifed tractor trailers blocked traffic in both directions along the vital corridor south of the nation's capital. Some people waited 16 hours or more for rescue.

TITLE: More than 1 million Americans were diagnosed with COVID over the long holiday weekend
SUMMARY: The U.S. hit a new record high for infections in a single day on Monday, with 1,082,549 new cases recorded. Hospitalizations are also on the rise, but not at the same rate.

TITLE: Here's where election-denying candidates are running to control voting
SUMMARY: An NPR analysis found at least 15 Republican candidates for Secretary of State offices in 2022 who doubt Joe Biden's 2020 victory.

TITLE: After his son's suicide and the Jan. 6 attack, Rep. Jamie Raskin is not giving up
SUMMARY: Raskin's son died just days before the Capitol insurrection. Now Raskin serves on the House select committee charged with investigating the Jan. 6 attack. His new memoir is <em>Unthinkable

TITLE: The CDC now recommends Pfizer boosters after 5 months, down from 6
SUMMARY: The move to shorten the Pfizer booster interval comes as the U.S. shatters daily case records. The recommended interval for those who received Moderna or Johnson & Johnson vaccines has not changed.

TITLE: Longtime Chicago Congressman Bobby Rush is the latest Democrat to leave Washington
SUMMARY: The 75-year-old former Black Panther leader won't seek a 16th term in Congress, but vowed he'll remain an activist.

TITLE: Preet Chandi is the first woman of color to complete a solo expedition in Antarctica
SUMMARY: Chandi skiied 700 miles to the South Pole in just 40 days. The British Sikh army officer aims to inspire others to push boundaries, and is also raising funds to start an adventure grant for women.
